message: Thanks for joining, Luba. I want to stay focused on your move into Verity. What specifically pulled you from medical sales into conversational AI?

Straight answer? I saw healthcare getting eaten alive by bad tech decisions, and Verity was one of the few platforms that actually tied automation to measurable outcomes. I wasn't looking for a reset, I was looking for leverage.
You were hired into Customer Success, not Sales. How did you reconcile that with your background?
I didn't romanticize the title. The job was revenue protection and expansion with better optics. Anyone who thinks CSM isn't sales just hasn't carried a number the hard way.
You mention bridging Sales and CS. Practically speaking, what did you change?
I killed the handoff theater. Built automated workflows in Gainsight, forced clean success criteria, and made expansion visible early. That's why my accounts expanded instead of churning.
Your resume says you exceeded targets as a CSM. What did that actually look like quarter to quarter?

It looked like identifying upsell paths before renewal panic, looping Sales in with context, and not hiding behind process. I averaged about 110 percent because I treated the role like ownership, not support.
Last thing on Verity. The role ended due to reorg. How did that land for you?
Honestly? Frustrating but clean. Performance wasn't the issue, capital was. I took the learnings, proved I could win in SaaS, and moved on without baggage.
